questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the organization of the nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: Gray matter in the CNS is called a nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: PNS ganglia are mostly derived from the neural tube.

options.label: C
options.text: White matter in the CNS forms structures like tracts and fasciculi.

options.label: D
options.text: Axons in the CNS are covered by oligodendrocytes, and in the PNS by Schwann cells

questions.correct_answer: B. PNS ganglia are mostly derived from the neural tube.

questions.text: A 30 year old patient presents with sudden vision loss in one eye and pain during eye movement. The patient has a history of recurrent neurological symptoms and Imaging studies reveal inflammation and demyelination of the optic nerve. The patient is diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS). Why is the optic nerve affected in MS, despite being considered a peripheral nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: The optic nerve is not affected by MS.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an extension of the diencephalon and is myelinated by Schwann cells, which are affected in MS.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an extension of the diencephalon and myelinated by oligodendrocytes, which are involved in MS.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not regenerate, making it more vulnerable to damage.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is an extension of the diencephalon and myelinated by oligodendrocytes, which are involved in MS.

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly identifies the true statement about the formation of the neural tube? Neural plate → Neural groove → Neural tube The anterior neuropore closes on day 28 The posterior neuropore closes around day 25

options.label: A
options.text: 1 is correc

options.label: B
options.text: 2 and 3 is correct

options.label: C
options.text: 1 and 2 is correct

options.label: D
options.text: All are correct

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of ectodermal placodes?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing into the lens vesicle

options.label: B
options.text: Forming the olfactory epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Contributing to the development of the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear

options.label: D
options.text: Directly gives rise to neurons in the Vestibulocochlear ganglion

questions.correct_answer: D. Directly gives rise to neurons in the Vestibulocochlear ganglion
questions.explanation:
Important Placodes

Hypophysial Placode

Forms Rathke’s pouch (future pituitary gland).

Olfactory Placode

Develops into nasal cavity epithelium. (Option B)

Epibranchial Placodes

Contribute to facial, glossopharyngeal, and vagus ganglia.

Otic Placodes

Develop into the inner ear (membranous labyrinth) structures. (Option C)

Trigeminal Placodes

Contribute to trigeminal ganglia.

questions.text: Which of the following structural abnormalities is most commonly associated with the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: Malformation of the vertebral arches

options.label: B
options.text: Incomplete development of the basichondrocranium

options.label: C
options.text: Herniation of brain tissue through the skull

options.label: D
options.text: Fusion of the cranial sutures

questions.correct_answer: B. Incomplete development of the basichondrocranium
questions.explanation:
Neural Tube Defect

Description

Anencephaly (Cranioschisis)

Failure of neural tube fusion in the brain region, results in missing parts of the brain and skull.

Craniorachischisis Totalis

Complete failure of the neural tube to fuse, affecting both the brain and spinal cord.

Spina Bifida

Incomplete fusion of the spinal neural tube or failure of formation of vertebral arches leads to defects in the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common feature of craniorachischisis compared to rachischisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Craniorachischisis results from failure of caudal neural tube closure, while rachischisis affects the entire tube.

options.label: B
options.text: Craniorachischisis exposes both the brain and spinal cord; rachischisis exposes only the spinal cord.

options.label: C
options.text: Craniorachischisis is less severe than rachischisis and affects only the vertebrae.

options.label: D
options.text: Craniorachischisis involves complete neural tube closure, while rachischisis exposes both the brain and spinal cord.

questions.correct_answer: B. Craniorachischisis exposes both the brain and spinal cord; rachischisis exposes only the spinal cord.
questions.explanation:
Condition

Rachischisis

Craniorachischisis

Description

A type of spina bifida where a portion of the spinal cord remains open.

The most severe form of neural tube defect- involving exposure of both the brain and spinal cord.

Neural Tube Involvement

Occurs due to the failure of fusion of the caudal portion of the neural tube. (Option A)

Occurs due to the failure of fusion of both the cranial as well as the caudal portions of the neural tube.

(Option D)

Severity

Severe, but localised to the spinal cord

Most severe

(Option C)

Exposure

Spinal cord neural tissue is exposed

Both the brain and spinal cord are exposed.

Diagram

questions.text: Which of the following statements about spina bifida is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Spina bifida occulta presents with an abnormal U or V shape in the vertebrae.

options.label: B
options.text: Meningocele involves protrusion of the meninges and spinal cord through the defect.

options.label: C
options.text: Diastematomyelia is rarely associated with spina bifida and splits the spinal cord.

options.label: D
options.text: The incidence of myelomeningocele has decreased due to prenatal diagnosis and termination options.

questions.correct_answer: B. Meningocele involves protrusion of the meninges and spinal cord through the defect.
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Spina Bifida Cystica

Involves a visible sac or cyst containing the spinal cord or nerves protruding from the back.Two types:

  • Meningocele: A sac containing only the meninges and CSF, with the spinal cord intact.
  • Myelomeningocele: Sac contains both the meninges and a portion of the spinal cord; the most severe form.

Spina Bifida Occulta

The defect is hidden under the skin, typically found in the lumbosacral or sacral regions; it affects ~5% of the population.

Impact

Description

Ascent of the Conus Medullaris

The conus medullaris normally ascends relative to the vertebral column. In spina bifida, this ascent is impaired, leading to a tethered cord.

Tethered Cord

The spinal cord is anchored at the defect site, restricting normal upward movement, which can cause neurological complications.

Diastematomyelia

An extremely rare condition where the spinal cord is split into two columns by a bony or cartilaginous spur, often associated with tethered cord. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following correctly pairs a brain region with its corresponding structure or function?

options.label: A
options.text: Myelencephalon: Develops into the cerebellum, involved in motor control and balance.

options.label: B
options.text: Tectum: Located in the hindbrain and responsible for auditory and visual reflexes.

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothalamus: Part of the diencephalon, regulates hunger, thirst, body temperature, and sleep-wake cycles.

options.label: D
options.text: Frontal Lobe: Primarily involved in visual processing and spatial awareness.

questions.correct_answer: C. Hypothalamus: Part of the diencephalon, regulates hunger, thirst, body temperature, and sleep-wake cycles.
questions.explanation:
Brain Region

Components

Functions/Derivatives

Prosencephalon (Forebrain)

Diencephalon

Relay centre for sensory information, regulates endocrine system, autonomic functions
  • Thalamus

Relays sensory information to the cerebral cortex.
  • Hypothalamus

Regulates hunger, thirst, temperature, sleep-wake cycles, endocrine system
  • Epithalamus

The pineal gland (melatonin production)
  • Subthalamus

Involved in motor control

Telencephalon

Forms cerebral hemispheres, median part in front of the interventricular foramen and lateral ventricle

Cerebral Cortex

Higher cognitive functions (language, memory, reasoning, movement)
  • Frontal Lobe (Option D)

Planning, decision-making, problem-solving, voluntary movement
  • Parietal Lobe

Sensory information, spatial awareness, navigation
  • Temporal Lobe

Auditory processing, language comprehension
  • Occipital Lobe

Visual processing

Lateral Ventricles

Fluid-filled cavities for cerebrospinal fluid circulation

Mesencephalon (Midbrain)

Cerebral Peduncles

Connects cerebrum to the brainstem

Tectum (Option B)

Made of superior and inferior colliculi.

Tegmentum

Contains nuclei of 5,6,7,8 nerves.

Rhombencephalon (Hindbrain)

Myelencephalon (Option A)

Develops into the medulla oblongata (breathing, heart rate)

Metencephalon

Forms the pons (signal relay) and cerebellum (motor control, balance)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the treatment of aqueduct stenosis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting permanently cures aqueduct stenosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopic third ventriculostomy involves diverting CSF to the abdominal cavity.

options.label: C
options.text: Aqueduct stenosis can be treated with medications alone in most cases.

options.label: D
options.text: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting involves diverting CSF to reduce intracranial pressure.

questions.correct_answer: D. Ventriculoperitoneal shunting involves diverting CSF to reduce intracranial pressure.
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Causes
  • Congenital: Developmental anomalies
  • Acquired: Tumours, infections, trauma

Symptoms
  • Headache, nausea, vomiting (Due to CSF accumulation)
  • Cognitive impairments due to increased intracranial pressure.

Diagnosis
  • MRI or CT scans showing aqueduct narrowing and ventricular enlargement.

Treatment


 
  • Ventriculoperitoneal shunting: Diverts excess CSF (Option A)
  • Endoscopic third ventriculostomy: Bypasses obstruction (high relapse rate) (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the cerebellar peduncles and corpora quadrigemina is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior cerebellar peduncles carry afferent signals from the cerebellum to the medulla.

options.label: B
options.text: Middle cerebellar peduncles transmit sensory information from the spinal cord to the cerebellum.

options.label: C
options.text: Inferior cerebellar peduncles connect the cerebellum to the medulla and aid in balance and posture.

options.label: D
options.text: Superior colliculi are involved in auditory processing and relay signals to the auditory cortex.

questions.correct_answer: C. Inferior cerebellar peduncles connect the cerebellum to the medulla and aid in balance and posture.
questions.explanation:
Cerebellar Peduncles

Peduncle

Function

Components

Role

Superior Cerebellar Peduncles

Carry efferent (outgoing) signals from the cerebellum to the midbrain.

(Option A)

 

Connects the cerebellum to the midbrain.

It contains axons from the Dentate, Emboliform and the Globose nuclei of the cerebellum.

Movement planning and coordination.

Middle Cerebellar Peduncles

The main route for afferent (incoming) signals to the cerebellum.

Connects cerebellum to the pons.

(Option B)

Provides information about planned movements.

Inferior Cerebellar Peduncles

(Option C)

Carry both afferent and efferent fibres.

 

Connects cerebellum to the medulla oblongata.

It contains axons from the fastigial nucleus of the cerebellum.

Receives sensory information for balance and posture, and sends signals to vestibular nuclei and reticular formation.

Corpora Quadrigemina (Tectum)

Colliculi

Function

Components

Role

Superior Colliculi

Involved in visual processing and eye movement control.

(Option D)

Receives input from optic nerves and visual processing areas.

Coordinates head and eye movements in response to visual stimuli.

Inferior Colliculi

Plays a role in auditory processing.

[musIC- Inferior Colliculus]

Receives input from auditory pathways.

Projects to the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus for auditory signal relay.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structures in the given diagram.

options.label: A
options.text: A- Fornix; B- Hippocampus; C- Corpus Callosum

options.label: B
options.text: A – Fornix; B – Amygdala; C – Hippocampus

options.label: C
options.text: A- Fornix; B- Corpus Callosum; C- Hippocampus

options.label: D
options.text: A – Fornix; B – Hypothalamus; C – Amygdala

questions.correct_answer: C. A- Fornix; B- Corpus Callosum; C- Hippocampus
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Thalamus

Grey matter mass; sensory and motor roles

Fornix

A c-shaped fibre bundle; connects the hippocampal formations of the two sides. The main efferent tract of the hippocampus.

Corpus Callosum

The largest commissure of the brain; links the cerebra hemispheres.

Caudate Nucleus

The comma-shaped nucleus of the basal ganglia

Choroid Plexus

Produces CSF; vascular network.

Hippocampus

Seahorse-shaped (Curved and elongated); stores long-term memory and is a part of the limbic system.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the pathway of the Papez circuit?

options.label: A
options.text: Cingulate cortex → Hippocampus → Mammillary bodies → Anterior thalamic nuclei → Fornix

options.label: B
options.text: Cingulate cortex → Mammillary bodies → Hippocampus → Fornix → Anterior thalamic nuclei

options.label: C
options.text: Hippocampus → Cingulate cortex → Anterior thalamic nuclei → Mammillary bodies → Fornix

options.label: D
options.text: Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies → Anterior thalamic nuclei → Cingulate cortex

questions.correct_answer: D. Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies → Anterior thalamic nuclei → Cingulate cortex
